form_description: A project represents a study or experiment that groups related sequencing orders. Each project can contain multiple orders for different samples or time points.

fields.label: Project Title
fields.help_text: Choose a descriptive title that clearly identifies your research project or study.

content.title: Guidelines for Project Title
guidelines: **Descriptive:** Clearly indicate the main focus of your research
**Specific:** Include key details like organism, condition, or methodology

examples.title: Good Examples:
items: Gut Microbiome Diversity in Patients with Inflammatory Bowel Disease
Comparative Metagenomics of Arctic Soil Microbial Communities
RNA-Seq Analysis of E. coli Response to Antibiotic Stress

warnings.title: Avoid:
items: Generic titles like 'Microbiome Study' or 'Sequencing Project'
Internal project codes as the main title

fields.label: Project Alias
fields.help_text: A short, unique identifier for your project (e.g., internal code or lab abbreviation).

content.title: Project Alias Guidelines
content.description: The alias serves as a short, memorable identifier for your project. It's often used in file naming and internal references.

format_recommendations.title: Format Recommendations:
items: **Characters:** Letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores only
**Case:** Either all uppercase or consistent casing

content.tips: Choose an alias that will still make sense to you and your team in 2-3 years. Avoid using only numbers or overly cryptic abbreviations.

fields.label: Project Description
fields.help_text: Include research objectives, sample types, experimental design, and expected outcomes.
fields.placeholder: Provide a detailed description of your study objectives, sample types, and experimental design...

content.title: Writing an Effective Project Description
content.description: A comprehensive project description helps reviewers understand your research and ensures proper sample processing.

sections.title: 1. Research Background (2-3 sentences)
sections.description: Briefly explain the context and importance of your study.
sections.example: The human gut microbiome plays a crucial role in health and disease. Recent studies suggest altered microbial composition in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

sections.title: 2. Objectives and Hypotheses
sections.description: Clearly state what you aim to discover or prove.

sections.title: 3. Sample Information
items: **Sample types:** stool, soil, water, tissue, etc.
**Number of samples:** total count and groups

sections.title: 5. Expected Outcomes
sections.description: What do you hope to achieve?

content.length_guidelines: Aim for 200-500 words. Be comprehensive but concise. Include all relevant details that would help the sequencing facility understand and properly process your samples.

fields.label: Already submitted to ENA
fields.help_text: Check this only if this project has already been submitted to the European Nucleotide Archive (ENA) and has received an accession number.

fields.label: Study Accession ID
fields.help_text: Automatically populated after ENA submission (Format: PRJEB######)
fields.placeholder: Will be assigned after ENA submission
